articles.headline: In China, Facebook Tests the Waters With a Stealth App
articles.snippet: The social media giant has quietly authorized the release of a Chinese version of its Moments app, a highly unusual move that raises transparency questions.
articles.abstract: The social media giant has quietly authorized the release of a Chinese version of its Moments app, a highly unusual move that raises transparency questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Facebook and many of its apps have been blocked in China for years. To change that, Mark Zuckerberg has made a big point of meeting with Chinese politicians, reading stodgy Communist Party propaganda, studying Mandarin and — perhaps more daunting — speaking it in public.

articles.headline: The Fed Wants to Make Life Easier for Big-Bank Directors
articles.snippet: In a flawed proposal, the regulator would reduce interactions between bank examiners and boards, giving managers more leeway to address internal ills.
articles.abstract: In a flawed proposal, the regulator would reduce interactions between bank examiners and boards, giving managers more leeway to address internal ills.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amid reports Thursday that Stephen Sanger, chairman of the Wells Fargo board, may step down in the coming months, all eyes are on the bank’s directors and their oversight of the troubled institution.

articles.headline: The Incredible Shrinking Sears
articles.snippet: How a financial wizard took over a giant of American retailing, and presided over its epic decline.
articles.abstract: How a financial wizard took over a giant of American retailing, and presided over its epic decline.
articles.lead_paragraph: Imagine a retailer that began by specializing in just one product, then grew into a mammoth that redefined the American shopping experience.

articles.headline: To Fit Into Silicon Valley, Wear These Wool Shoes
articles.snippet: Silicon Valley has gone through many shoe style trends, including Crocs and Vibrams. Now it’s Allbirds, the wool shoe that techies love to wear.
articles.abstract: Silicon Valley has gone through many shoe style trends, including Crocs and Vibrams. Now it’s Allbirds, the wool shoe that techies love to wear.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Silicon Valley goes through its own unique shoe crazes. There were Vibrams. There were Crocs.

articles.headline: Scott Pruitt Is Carrying Out His E.P.A. Agenda in Secret, Critics Say
articles.snippet: He has made it clear that he intends to dismantle the E.P.A.’s environmental mission. His critics say he is deploying extraordinary secrecy as he does so.
articles.abstract: He has made it clear that he intends to dismantle the E.P.A.’s environmental mission. His critics say he is deploying extraordinary secrecy as he does so.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When career employees of the Environmental Protection Agency are summoned to a meeting with the agency’s administrator, Scott Pruitt, at agency headquarters, they no longer can count on easy access to the floor where his office is, according to interviews with employees of the federal agency.
articles.byline: By Coral Davenport and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: A Crisis Forces Google to Uphold Its Values While Fostering Debate
articles.snippet: Employees are encouraged to speak up in online forums, but those forums have become heated over an internal memo that questioned the role of women in tech.
articles.abstract: Employees are encouraged to speak up in online forums, but those forums have become heated over an internal memo that questioned the role of women in tech.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As a crisis unfurled at Google over an employee memo that argued biological factors helped explain the shortage of female engineers and leaders in Silicon Valley, some of the most pointed critiques of the company’s handing of the issue were posted to its own message boards.

articles.headline: ‘We’ve Had Enough’: Conservatives Relish the ‘Fury’ in Trump’s Talk
articles.snippet: Conservatives in the mainland United States are celebrating the idea of potentially taking down someone they see as a bully.
articles.abstract: Conservatives in the mainland United States are celebrating the idea of potentially taking down someone they see as a bully.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — “Fire and fury”? Eugene Yu could not have said it better himself.

articles.headline: Man Charged After White Nationalist Rally in Charlottesville Ends in Deadly Violence
articles.snippet: Protests of a plan to remove a statue of a Confederate general led to clashes that left at least one person dead and 34 others injured, officials said.
articles.abstract: Protests of a plan to remove a statue of a Confederate general led to clashes that left at least one person dead and 34 others injured, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — The city of Charlottesville was engulfed by violence on Saturday as white nationalists and counterprotesters clashed in one of the bloodiest fights to date over the removal of Confederate monuments across the South.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Brian M. Rosenthal

articles.headline: Mueller Is Said to Seek Interviews With West Wing in Russia Case
articles.snippet: Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel, is said to be in talks about interviewing current and former senior officials, including Reince Priebus, the recently ousted chief of staff.
articles.abstract: Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel, is said to be in talks about interviewing current and former senior officials, including Reince Priebus, the recently ousted chief of staff.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a sign that the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election will remain a continuing distraction for the White House, the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, is in talks with the West Wing about interviewing current and former senior administration officials, including the recently ousted White House chief of staff, Reince Priebus, according to three people briefed on the discussions.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt, Matt Apuzzo and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Trump Eyes China Sanctions While Seeking Its Help on North Korea
articles.snippet: The American president is trying to enlist Beijing in his struggle with North Korea even as the White House is set to announce trade crackdown.
articles.abstract: The American president is trying to enlist Beijing in his struggle with North Korea even as the White House is set to announce trade crackdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In a diplomatic gamble, President Trump is seeking to enlist China as a peacemaker in the bristling nuclear-edged dispute with North Korea at the very moment he plans to ratchet up conflict with Beijing over trade issues that have animated his political rise.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Trump Threats Are Wild Card in Showdown With North Korea
articles.snippet: Many in Washington and capitals across the Pacific are wondering whether President Trump’s fusillade of apocalyptic threats was more method or madness.
articles.abstract: Many in Washington and capitals across the Pacific are wondering whether President Trump’s fusillade of apocalyptic threats was more method or madness.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRIDGEWATER, N.J. — After a four-day fusillade of apocalyptic threats against North Korea, President Trump left many in Washington and capitals throughout the Pacific wondering whether it was more method or madness. Among those wondering were members of Mr. Trump’s own administration.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Stay, Hide or Leave? Hard Choices for Immigrants in the Heartland
articles.snippet: Edith Rivera loved her life in Hampton, Iowa, but for many undocumented immigrants like her, this summer has been a season of fear or flight.
articles.abstract: Edith Rivera loved her life in Hampton, Iowa, but for many undocumented immigrants like her, this summer has been a season of fear or flight.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAMPTON, Iowa — It was quitting time. Edith Rivera took one last lunch order, dropped off a basket of tortilla chips and set off from work, heading out to the farm roads where other immigrants feared to drive.

articles.headline: Hurt and Angry, Charlottesville Tries to Regroup From Violence
articles.snippet: After a white nationalist rally led to melees and the death of a 32-year-old woman, the city tried to recover — as the police, in particular, came in for criticism.
articles.abstract: After a white nationalist rally led to melees and the death of a 32-year-old woman, the city tried to recover — as the police, in particular, came in for criticism.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — Brittany Caine-Conley, a minister in training at Sojourners United Church of Christ, arrived in downtown Charlottesville on Saturday morning expecting that there might be violence. She did not expect things to get out of hand so quickly.

articles.headline: White House Acts to Stem Fallout From Trump’s First Charlottesville Remarks
articles.snippet: A statement from the White House, under siege over President Trump’s initial comments, on Sunday condemned “white supremacists” for inciting violence that left a woman dead.
articles.abstract: A statement from the White House, under siege over President Trump’s initial comments, on Sunday condemned “white supremacists” for inciting violence that left a woman dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRIDGEWATER, N.J. — White House officials, under siege over President Trump’s reluctance to condemn white supremacists for the weekend’s bloody rallies in Charlottesville, Va., tried to clarify his comments on Sunday, as critics in both parties intensified demands that he adopt a stronger, more unifying message.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Rebecca R. Ruiz

articles.headline: Teaching A.I. Systems to Behave Themselves
articles.snippet: As philosophers and pundits worry that artificial intelligence will one day harm the world, some researchers are working on ways to lower the risks.
articles.abstract: As philosophers and pundits worry that artificial intelligence will one day harm the world, some researchers are working on ways to lower the risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — At OpenAI, the artificial intelligence lab founded by Tesla’s chief executive, Elon Musk, machines are teaching themselves to behave like humans. But sometimes, this goes wrong.

articles.headline: The Messy, Confusing Future of TV? It’s Here
articles.snippet: We’ve rushed headlong into a hyper-fragmented mess, with a jumble of on-demand services that, added up, cost more and often offer less than the old cable bundle.
articles.abstract: We’ve rushed headlong into a hyper-fragmented mess, with a jumble of on-demand services that, added up, cost more and often offer less than the old cable bundle.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re like me and the millions of other Americans who have canceled a cable television subscription over the past few years, you’re probably familiar with the phenomenon I’ve started calling “the hunt.”

articles.headline: EBay’s Founder Has a New Idea: Build a Dairy in Hawaii
articles.snippet: Kauai residents who object are teaming up with owners of resorts that line the island’s famous beaches to try to block the dairy.
articles.abstract: Kauai residents who object are teaming up with owners of resorts that line the island’s famous beaches to try to block the dairy.
articles.lead_paragraph: KAUAI, Hawaii — If Pierre Omidyar gets his way, 699 dairy cows will soon enjoy a glorious view of the Pacific Ocean, framed by a pristine beach.

articles.headline: Uber Board Considers 3 Investment Offers to Buy Company’s Shares
articles.snippet: Even as the ride-hailing service’s future remains unclear, Uber’s board has debated three investment offers that could affect the company’s power structure.
articles.abstract: Even as the ride-hailing service’s future remains unclear, Uber’s board has debated three investment offers that could affect the company’s power structure.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber’s board has voted to move forward on proposals by two investment groups to buy shares in the ride-hailing service and is considering a third offer, with any final decision set to affect who gains the upper hand at the company.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Katie Benner

articles.headline: In Total Eclipse’s Path, Hope and Uncertainty in Rural Kentucky
articles.snippet: Wickliffe, in western Kentucky, thought about cashing in on the eclipse by inviting viewers. But then its mayor started to worry about the crowds.
articles.abstract: Wickliffe, in western Kentucky, thought about cashing in on the eclipse by inviting viewers. But then its mayor started to worry about the crowds.
articles.lead_paragraph: WICKLIFFE, Ky. — A bluff south of the downtown, topped by a 95-foot metal cross, overlooks the states of Missouri and Illinois, and the convergence of the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers.

articles.headline: How a Conservative TV Giant Is Ridding Itself of Regulation
articles.snippet: The Sinclair Broadcast Group and the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission see eye to eye on the need to unleash television. Both are reaping big rewards.
articles.abstract: The Sinclair Broadcast Group and the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission see eye to eye on the need to unleash television. Both are reaping big rewards.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The day before President Trump’s inauguration, the top executive of the Sinclair Broadcast Group, the nation’s largest owner of television stations, invited an important guest to the headquarters of the company’s Washington-area ABC affiliate.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang, Eric Lipton and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Netflix Signs Shonda Rhimes in Counterpunch to ABC and Disney
articles.snippet: Her shows “Grey’s Anatomy” and “Scandal” will stay at ABC, but Ms. Rhimes has an exclusive deal to create projects for the streaming giant Netflix.
articles.abstract: Her shows “Grey’s Anatomy” and “Scandal” will stay at ABC, but Ms. Rhimes has an exclusive deal to create projects for the streaming giant Netflix.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a huge blow to ABC and Disney, the prolific television hitmaker Shonda Rhimes has signed an exclusive overall deal with Netflix, that streaming giant announced early Monday morning.

articles.headline: North Korea’s Missile Success Is Linked to Ukrainian Plant, Investigators Say
articles.snippet: Investigators are focusing on the factory as a black-market source for North Korea, a new report and classified intelligence assessments say.
articles.abstract: Investigators are focusing on the factory as a black-market source for North Korea, a new report and classified intelligence assessments say.
articles.lead_paragraph: North Korea’s success in testing an intercontinental ballistic missile that appears able to reach the United States was made possible by black-market purchases of powerful rocket engines probably from a Ukrainian factory with historical ties to Russia’s missile program, according to an expert analysis being published Monday and classified assessments by American intelligence agencies.
articles.byline: By William J. Broad and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: New Outcry as Trump Rebukes Charlottesville Racists 2 Days Later
articles.snippet: President Trump bowed to pressure that he personally condemn white supremacists who incited violence in Virginia, but neither supporters nor critics were satisfied.
articles.abstract: President Trump bowed to pressure that he personally condemn white supremacists who incited violence in Virginia, but neither supporters nor critics were satisfied.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The crisis in Charlottesville, Va., presented President Trump with a choice between adopting the unifying tone of a traditional president or doubling down on the go-it-alone approach that got him elected in 2016.

articles.headline: Seeking Greater Global Power, China Looks to Robots and Microchips
articles.snippet: The country’s effort to take a lead in the technologies of the future, often with the help of foreign companies, is the subject of a United States trade investigation.
articles.abstract: The country’s effort to take a lead in the technologies of the future, often with the help of foreign companies, is the subject of a United States trade investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In Chinese schools, students learn that the United States became a great nation partly by stealing technology from Britain. In the halls of government, officials speak of the need to inspire innovation by protecting inventions. In boardrooms, executives strategize about using infringement laws to fell foreign rivals.
